Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Storing, Querying and Re-Using Provenance of Computational Tasks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Workflow-based systems have emerged as an alternative to ad-hoc
approaches to data exploration that are widely used in the scientific
community. Workflows can capture computational tasks at various levels
of detail and systematically record the provenance (history) information
necessary for reproducibility, result publication and
sharing. Although the benefits of using scientific workflow systems
are well known, the fact that workflows are hard to create and
maintain has been a major barrier to wider adoption of the technology
in the scientific domain.

The goal of this project is to produce new algorithms and techniques
for exploring and re-using useful knowledge embedded in workflow
specifications and in the provenance of the data they manipulate.
This project addresses key limitations in existing workflow
systems. First, it develops a set of usable tools that enable casual
users (who do not necessarily have programming expertise) to perform
exploratory tasks and solve problems through workflows. These include
intuitive user interfaces to manipulate collections of workflow and to
query workflows by example. Second, it builds a scalable provenance
management infrastructure to support the efficient execution of these
operations.

The research results of this project advance the state of the art and
build fundamental knowledge in storing, querying, and re-using
provenance of computational tasks. This project has the potential to
impact a variety of applications where the creation and maintenance of
workflows is currently a major bottleneck. This includes large
computational science projects and portals. Furthermore, it makes
workflows and workflow technology more accessible to casual users.
Through our interdisciplinary collaborations, this project will have
immediate impact in helping improve the scientific discovery process.
The involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in the project
will provide mentoring opportunities. The PI is committed to
recruiting minority students. The results of this project will be
disseminated as research papers and as freely available tools at the
project website:
http://www.cs.utah.edu/~juliana/projects/NSF-IIS-0746500

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the greatest research challenges of the 21st century is to effectively understand and leverage the growing wealth of scientific data. To analyze and understand this data, complex computational processes need to be assembled, often requiring the combination of loosely-coupled resources, specialized libraries, distributed computing infrastructure, and Web services. Workflow systems have emerged as alternatives to the ad-hoc approaches commonly used in the scientific community tointegrate existing applications. Not only do workflow systems support the automation of repetitive tasks, but they can also capture complex computational processes at various levels of detail and systematically capture provenance information for the derived data products.  But as workflow technology moves from business to scientific environments, several challenges arise. Whereas business workflows are primarily used to automate repetitive processes, scientific workflows are often used in exploratory tasks, where change is the norm---in the course of data analysis and visualization, workflows are iteratively refined as users formulate and test hypotheses. Furthermore, scientific workflows need to cater wide variety of users, including many who do not have programming expertise.
In this project, we adopted a data-centric view of workflow-based computational processes, where the workflows and information about their evolution are stored, along with their impact on the data they manipulate.  This information captures detailed provenance of the steps followed in exploratory processes. It contains useful knowledge that can be re-used to aid in the construction and refinement of workflows and to enable users to solve problems collaboratively.  An important goal of our research was to build usable tools. As the need for information systems grows in a wide range of applications, notably in the scientific domain, usability is of paramount importance.  We have developed new operations and intuitive interfaces that allow casual users to query and manipulate large collections of workflows and their provenance.  And to support these operations, we have designed a provenance management infrastructure to efficiently store and query provenance information. Last, but not least, we have explored novel applications of provenance, notably, to support the publication of reproducible results and to support teaching.
Intellectual Merit
This project led to the development of a number of novel methods and tools for provenance management, covering provenance models, querying and analytics, and systems.
We designed a provenance model inspired on temporal databases that combines database and workflow provenance in a single framework. We studied the problem of provenance reorganization and developed algorithms to optimize the storage of workflow evolution provenance as well as present the information in a more intuitive way. We also contributed to the Open Provenance Model.
We developed mechanisms for querying provenance at different levels, including workflow evolution, the actual workflow, and execution logs. We worked on clustering strategies for large workflow collections and proposed different representations for workflow graphs that led to high-quality clusters at a low computational cost.
We developed an approach that simplifies the creation, maintenance, and use of customized workflow-based applications (or mashups). While this framework simplifies the job of an application designer, it gives an end-user the flexibility to create derived products and visualizations through a simple interface that hides unnecessary details of the underlying workflows and how they are integrated.   We introduced the notion of a strong link which reliably captures the connection between a workflow instance and data it derives, i.e., between the data and its provenance...
